RESIGNATION OF SPEAKER


    The Clerk: I have to inform Honourable Members that I had on the 5th day of August, 1966, at 4.30 p.m., received a letter under the hand of Mr Arumugam Ponnu Rajah resigning his office as Speaker of this Parliament.

    The office of Speaker is therefore vacant and under clause (1) of Article 24 of the Constitution, Honourable Members shall elect a person to fill that office.

Column: 176

ELECTION OF SPEAKER


    The Deputy Prime Minister (Dr Toh Chin Chye) stood up, and addressing himself to the Clerk of Parliament said: Mr Lopez, I propose,

    That Mr P. Coomaraswamy do take the Chair of this Parliament as Speaker.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Affairs (Mr Chan Chee Seng) stood up, and addressing himself to the Clerk of Parliament said: I support the proposal.

    There being no other proposal, the Clerk then declared P. Coomaraswamy to have been elected as Speaker of Parliament.

Administration of Oath


    Mr Speaker, standing at the Table, made Affirmation of Allegiance.

    Mr Speaker went to the Chair and sat down.

    Then the Mace (which before lay below the Table) was placed upon the Table.

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: Mr Speaker, Sir, may I say a few words of congratulations to you on behalf of the Government Benches on the occasion of your election as Speaker to the House?

    The House might want to know that Mr P. Coomaraswamy was born in Johore. He comes from Malaya as his predecessor did, was educated in the English College in Johore Bahru, and

Column: 177

subsequently studied law at Nottingham University where he was an active member of the Students' Union and also the President of the University Law Society.

    In 1956, Mr Coomaraswamy was called to the Bar at Lincoln's Inn and on returning to Singapore he entered into private practice as a member of the Singapore Bar. It might interest Government Members also to know that while in Singapore Mr Coomaraswamy did considerable public service in the interest of his profession. He was a member of the Law Faculty at the University of Singapore. He was also on the editorial board of the University Law Review and other bodies. Moreover, he was the Chairman of one of the many advisory committees on the Criminal Law (Temporary Provisions) Ordinance.

    Mr Coomaraswamy was also recruited as a member of the advisory committee on the P.P.S.O., and his services as a member of the public are perhaps best remembered as Secretary of the Singapore Bar Committee. In fact, I myself first met him in Select Committees of the House when he, representing the Singapore Bar Committee, came forward to give evidence on behalf of his colleagues.

    We are now very happy indeed that Mr Coomaraswamy, arising out of his legal expertise and experience, has been able to resign from his private practice in order to take up full-time duties as Speaker of this Parliament. You can be assured, Mr Speaker, Sir, that our side of the House will give you all the co-operation that you require, and I only wish that a Member of the Opposition were here today to say a few words on your election. But, unfortunately, their absence in this House is entirely beyond my control.

    Mr Speaker: Mr Prime Minister, the Leader and Members of the House, I thank the House for the honour it has done me and the confidence it has shown in me in electing me to the Chair of the House. That the House and each Member present here should think me worthy of the office makes me most humble.

Column: 178



    In becoming the Speaker, I am very conscious of my shortcomings. I am aware that I suffer by comparison with my distinguished predecessors. I have much to learn. Since you elected me as Deputy Speaker last February, I have received helpful and friendly guidance in very full measure from my immediate predecessor, Mr Speaker Rajah, and I have no doubt that you will join me in wishing him well in the new duties he has undertaken for the nation. For myself, I acknowledge my indebtedness and gratitude for his kindness to me both as a friend and mentor.

    In the performance of my duties, I will, as a new boy, ask you for your indulgence at all times and I trust you will show me every kindness even if I have from time to time to draw your attention to the provisions of the Standing Orders. However, in doing so, and at all times, I shall be, first and last, the servant of the House administering the rules of debate that the House has set for itself. I will uphold the dignity of the House and guard its privileges and those of its Members. I will endeavour to discharge my duties with patience and, if necessary, with firmness and at all times with impartiality. I shall ever be conscious that Government must get on with the vital business of governing, that Back-Benchers have their rights and that minorities must be heard. I have had in the last six months every help from the Clerk and the staff of the House. Let me say how much I appreciate the very efficient work done by them, in large part unseen and unheard. I know I can count on them for their continued good and loyal work.

    I thank you, Mr Deputy Prime Minister, for the very kind words that you have said.

    Let me once again, sincerely and in humility, thank Members for the great honour they have done me in calling me from outside their ranks, in more senses than one, to this distinguished seat.

ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

INTEGRATED SCHOOL IN SEMBAWANG


    1. Mr Teong Eng Siong asked the Minister for Education whether the Government has any plans to set up an Integrated School in the Sembawang Constituency for the enrolment of students in the English, Chinese, Malay and Tamil streams.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, there are no plans for the building of primary schools in the Sembawang constituency under the Second Plan.

    An extension of 16 classrooms has been approved under the 1966 programme for the Canberra School. This extension will be used to take over the primary classes in the Naval Base Full School and to absorb the increase in the intake of primary school students in the area. It will then be possible to admit children in the Malay, Chinese and Tamil language streams in the Government English schools in this area and to convert them into integrated schools.

    The Sembawang Malay School has 27 Malay and 14 English classes and is already an integrated school.

PRIVATE CLINICS AND DISPENSARIES
(Dispensation of poisons and dangerous drugs by unqualified personnel)


    4. Madam Chan Choy Siong asked the Minister for Health whether he is aware that in some clinics and dispensaries owned by doctors, the dispensing of poisons and dangerous drugs is carried out by unqualified personnel without the direct and personal supervision of the medical practitioner or qualified pharmacist, and whether he is contemplating steps to control the further employment of unqualified personnel in dispensing poisons and dangerous drugs.

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Mr Speaker, Sir, under existing law - to be precise, section 7 (4) of the Poisons Ordinance, Cap. 146 - doctors may both prescribe and dispense medicines, or have medicines dispensed under their supervision. In some advanced countries such as the United Kingdom and Scandinavia, doctoring is, however, kept separate from dispensing. Such a situation is possible only when there is a

Column: 181

sufficient number of qualified pharmacists available. In Singapore, at present, the number of doctors in private practice is 460, whereas the number of pharmacists in private practice is only 88.

    As the School of Pharmacy of our University of Singapore is now graduating annually about 20 to 25 pharmacists who are Singapore citizens, it will not be possible, for the present, to consider separation of dispensing from the function of doctoring, because such a restrictive practice, if implemented, whilst benefiting qualified pharmacists directly will, however, result in unqualified personnel now in the employ of doctors to lose their jobs, and worse still, the cost of services for treatment of patients may also rise in consequence.

    Madam Chan Choy Siong (Delta)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, just now the Minister for Health has given a reply to my question. But I would like to inform him that understandably if the Government were to implement certain laws, then certain unqualified but experienced people employed by doctors would be out of job. I would like to ask him whether he can make use of any law to prevent any future happening of this sort; in other words, while the present employees will not be affected, the practice will be stopped in future, so that unqualified people may not be employed in dispensing drugs. Of course, under any restrictive law, the pharmacist graduates may benefit, but we can perhaps see to it that in future there will not be any more unqualified people dispensing drugs.

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: I wish to assure the hon. Member for Delta that the question of looking after the interests of qualified pharmacists in Singapore is very much in the mind of the Ministry. In fact, we are having very close relationship with the School of Pharmacy authorities as well as the Malayan Pharmaceutical Association.

    It is felt that this is not quite the time to decide on restrictive practices. We are aware that there are a few graduates who have not been fixed up in employment. But this, I think, must take some

Column: 182

time because I do not think it should be regarded as a right by any graduate automatically to move into a job after graduation.

    As I have said earlier on, I can assure the Member that as soon as we feel that it is the right time to stop the employment of unqualified personnel, we shall do so. We are, in fact, making efforts to get pharmaceutical firms to employ qualified personnel as and when licences are being renewed. And because of this, a number of qualified pharmacists have, in fact, been employed.

GOVERNMENT OFFICERS
(Rudeness towards public)


    5. Mr Chow Chiok Hock asked the Minister for Finance whether he is aware of complaints of rudeness by some Government officers towards members of the public, and what action has been taken in the matter.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance (Mr S. Ramaswamy) (for the Minister for Finance): I am not aware of any complaints, but if the hon. Member is aware of any specific incident, he should let me have the details for an immediate investigation.

    The hon. Member may not be aware that there is adequate machinery to deal with allegations and offences of this nature. The Public Service (Disciplinary Proceedings - Delegation of Functions) Regulations were promulgated under the authority of the then Yang di-Pertuan Negara acting in accordance with the advice of the Public Service Commission in 1962. These Regulations authorise the Permanent Secretary in each Ministry to deal, among other things, with rudeness or discourtesy to the public by Government officials. Every such case is required to be investigated and, if proved true, the offender may be severely reprimanded and his record of service endorsed. More severe cases can be punished by forfeiture of up to half monthly salary or a fine of $200, whichever is less. The most severe cases may be reported by the Permanent Secretary concerned to the Public Service Commission for disciplinary action.

UNDESIRABLE MEDICAL ADVERTISEMENTS
IN CHINESE NEWSPAPERS


    6. Madam Chan Choy Siong asked the Minister for Culture and Social Affairs whether and what steps will be taken to eliminate undesirable medical advertisements appearing in Chinese newspapers.

    The Minister of State for Culture (Mr Lee Khoon Choy) (for the Minister for Culture and Social Affairs): Mr Speaker, Sir, an ad hoc Committee has been set up by the Ministry of Culture to study the problem of undesirable medical advertisements. The Committee held its first meeting on the 23rd of May, 1966. In the course of discussions at the meeting, it was learned that in 1962 a Committee was set up by the Ministry of Health under the chairmanship of Dr Gwee Ah Leng to study this and other related problems. Dr Gwen's Committee made recommendations for effecting certain amendments to the Medicine Advertisement and Sale Ordinance. It is considered that one of the proposed amendments, if made, will deal effectively with the problem under question.

    I understand further that the Minister for Health has already requested the Government Senior Physician, Dr Gwee Ah Leng, to resuscitate this Committee and to bring up to date their recommendations: the terms of reference of the Committee being to study the current unethical, dishonest, and undesirable advertisements pertaining to treatment, cure, to the medical skills of unqualified persons and to suggest measures of effective control. Members of the Committee will include representatives from the Attorney-General's Office, Culture, Social Affairs, the C.I.D., and the Controller and Registrar of Imports and Exports.

    Mr Ho See Beng (Bras Basah): Mr Speaker, Sir, regarding these medical advertisements in Chinese newspapers, I remember that the Member for Delta asked a similar question last year. I think she has in mind the advertisement

Column: 184

concerning abortions. The Government at that time said that it would put a stop to it. But almost a year has lapsed and nothing has been done. May I have an explanation from the Minister why nothing has been done to stop these advertisements?

    Mr Lee Khoon Choy: I can assure you, Mr Speaker, that all necessary measures to curb these undesirable activities have been taken by the Government.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Culture (Mr Fong Sip Chee): Mr Speaker, Sir, the question was first raised by the hon. Member for Delta at a sitting of Parliament on 28th December, 1965. On 19th January, 1966, I obtained copies of the Hansard with the relevant extracts and sent them down to the responsible officers in my Ministry to investigate into the matter. About 10 days after the 19th January, the Ministry of Culture began correspondence with the Ministry of Health on this subject, and discussions went on, and many matters came to light. On 9th March I put up a report to my Minister of State, explaining the circumstances and the various consequences that might result from any proposed amendment to the existing legislation. The question of new legislation was also explored. But it was later discovered that a Committee had been set up in 1962 the details of which had been explained earlier by my Minister of State.

    So you will notice, Mr Speaker, Sir, that since the question was brought up in December 1965, there has been no let-up and there has been a chain of continuous action on this problem. I assure the House that the Ministry of Culture will not allow such constructive criticisms to be left unanswered.

FOUNTAIN AT DELTA CIRCUS


    7. Madam Chan Choy Siong asked the Minister for Law and National Development whether he has plans to build more fountains, and if he will consider building a fountain at the Delta Circus.

Column: 185



    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for National Development (Mr Ho Cheng Choon) (for the Minister for Law and National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, there are no immediate plans to build more fountains in Singapore. However, the three fountains that have recently been erected have proved to be a great attraction and added to the sense of civic pride amongst the residents. These fountains, which are colourfully lit up at night, add grace to our city. In view of popular response, it is felt that more fountains should be built, especially at traffic circuses and in parks. When planning is done for future fountains and the sites are chosen, every consideration will be given to the building of a fountain at Delta Circus.
